FacilityName: City of Brownwood Wastewater Treatment Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Brownwood Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) treats wastewater from residential, commercial and industrial sectors of the City.  Wastewater is processed and treated with gaseous Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide, each of which is feed into the system from one ton containers.



Chlorine is stored as a liquid under pressure in the containers, and is supplied to the treatment system as a gas under vacuum.  Four one ton containers located outside under shade cover are connected to the Chlorine feed system.  Chlorine is fed from two containers at a time.  Feed is automatically switched to the second set of containers when the first set is empty.  Up to two additional containers are stored in the covered container storage area.



Sulfur Dioxide is also stored under pressure as a liquefied gas in one ton containers and is supplied to the treatment system as a gas under vacuum.



Two Sulfur Dioxide containers, located outdoors in and enclosed sheet metal storage box, are connected to the feed system.  Gas is fed to the treatment system from one container at a time.  Feed is automatically switched to the remaining container when the first is empty.  Up to two additional full sulfur dioxide containers are stored in covered container storage area.



Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide are delivered by truck in one ton containers from a regional supplier.  The plant operators use the facility's hoists to remove the containers from the delivery truck and place them on storage racks in each chemical storage area.



As a measure to protect against the occurrence of accidental chemical releases, periodic reviews are conducted to identify potential hazards associated with the equipment and procedures for the Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide system.  Any identified deficiencies, such as potential equipment malfunctions or human errors, must be documented and maintained.  Sets of standard operating procedures (SOP) are in place for proper storage, use, and handling of Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide

at the WWTP.  Operating procedures are in place to provide clear instructions to safely conduct activities associated with the Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide system.



To protect personal in the operation to the chemical feed systems, adequate training is provided for each employee involved with the process.  Proper operator training is a key element to the operation of the facility in a safe manner.  As part of the training system, refresher and update training are provided on a regular basis.



Preventive maintenance, inspection, and testing of equipment are vital to the proper operation of the facility.  Maintenance procedures are implemented for the equipment associated with each system.  A preventive maintenance schedule has been developed from equipment manufacturer and industry guidelines.  Personnel involved in the ongoing maintenance are trained in the maintenance procedures and in the hazards of the processes and all maintenance activities are documented for future references.



A system to investigate any accident or near miss involving Chlorine or Sulfur Dioxide is in place for each facility.  A report describing the cause and any effects of the incident is made followed by recommendations for corrective action.  The purpose of the incident investigation is to identify the cause of the problem, implement a safe solution, and ultimately prevent the situation from occurring again.  Incidents can be reviewed for similarities to determine if a trend is evident, possibly uncovering a previously unidentified root cause.  This provides for continually improving safety at the facility.



In the event an accidental release does occur at the facility, it is critical to be prepared to respond quickly, safely, and effectively to minimize the effects of the release.  Operators at the plant are qualified to respond to incidental Chlorine or Sulfur Dioxide leaks that do not pose an immediate threat to the individual.  The City of Brownwood Fire Department is responsi

ble for responding to significant Chlorine or Sulfur Dioxide leaks requiring evacuation of personnel.  Plant management staff coordinates with the Fire Department on a regular basis to maintain current facility information and planning and response capabilities. In a emergency situation, protection of personnel at the facility, notifications of emergency responders and evacuation to a safe location are the primary responsibilities of the employees at the plant.



With continued support from all levels of personnel, training and preventive maintenance we can make this facility as safe as possible.  In the event an accident does occur all personnel will be trained and ready to take immediate action to insure the safety of facility personnel and surrounding area.
